facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 49 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 49 of 1956. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 13, 1954 of Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 13, 1954, of the Madras High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 267 and 1954 1212

facts.text: Madras High Court judgment in Criminal Revision Case No. 267 of 1954 and Criminal Revision Petition No. 249 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: of the Madras High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 267 and 1954 1212  Criminal Revision Petition No. 249 of 1954  arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Arising out of judgment dated January 12, 1954 of District and Sessions Judge, Tiruchirapalli in Criminal Revision Petition No. 17 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Revision Petition No. 249 of 1954  arising out of the judgment and order dated January 12, 1954, of the Court of the District and Sessions Judge as Tiruchirapalli in Criminal Revision Petition No. 17 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 25, 1958 by SINHA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. August 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-The only question for determination in this appeal by special leave,

facts.text: Appellant filed petition of complaint in court of Additional First-Class Magistrate, Tiruchirappalli against three respondents.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellant filed a petition of companyplaint in the companyrt of the Additional First-Class Magistrate, Tiruchirappalli, against the respondents, three in number.

facts.text: Petition of complaint dated June 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On those allegations, the petition of companyplaint  dated June 5, 1953  prayed that processes might issue against the three accused persons.

facts.text: First accused is leader of Dravida Kazakam, a community professing to be religious reformers against idol worship.

anchor.surface_text: The petition of companyplaint alleged inter alia that the first accused is the leader of Dravida Kazakam  a companymunity of persons who profess to be religious reformers, one of whose creeds is to carry on propaganda against idol worship ,

facts.text: First accused announced intention of breaking image of God Ganesa on 27th May, 1953 in public meeting at Town Hall.

anchor.surface_text: and as such, be was out to vilify a certain section of the Hindu companymunity and do propaganda by holding meetings and writing articles. It is further alleged in the petition of companyplaint that recently, the first accused announced his intention of breaking the image of God Ganesa, the God sacred to the Saiva Section of the Hindu Community on 27th May, 1953, in a public meeting at Town Hall.

facts.text: Announcement caused terror in mind of Saivite Section of Hindu Community.

anchor.surface_text: This caused terror-commotion in the mind of the Saivite Section of the -Hindu Community. The companyplainant claims to be a Saivite.

facts.text: Complainant is a Saivite.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant claims to be a Saivite.

facts.text: On May 27, 1953 at 5:30 p.m., first accused broke idol of God Ganesa in public at Town Hall Maidan and made speech stating intention to insult feelings of Hindu community.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant further alleged in his petition that on May 27, 1953, at about 5-30 p.m., the accused broke an idol of God Ganesa in public at the Town Hall Maidan, and before breaking the idol, lie made a speech, and expressly stated that he intended to insult the feelings of the Hindu companymunity by breaking the idol of God 1213 Ganesa.

facts.text: Act of breaking idol abetted by instigation and aid by other two accused who made speeches.

anchor.surface_text: The said act of breaking the idol was alleged to have been actively abetted by instigation and aid by the other two accused persons, who also made speeches.

facts.text: Act done with intention of insulting religious feelings of sections of Hindu community who venerate God Ganesa.

anchor.surface_text: The petition of companyplaint also alleged that the said act of breaking the image of God Ganesa was done with the intention of insulting the religious feelings of certain sections of the Hindu companymunity, who hold God Ganesa in veneration,

facts.text: Magistrate examined complainant on oath on June 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date, the learned magistrate examined the companyplainant on oath. The companyplainant made statements in support of his allegations in the petition of companyplaint.

facts.text: Magistrate directed petition sent to Circle Inspector of Police, Trichy for inquiry under s.202 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the learned magistrate directed that the petition of companyplaint be sent to the Circle Inspector of police, Trichy, for inquiry and report under s. 202, Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: Police report received on June 26, 1953 stating occurrence took place but point of law if offence.

anchor.surface_text: On June 26, 1953, on receipt of the police report which showed that though the occurrence as alleged had taken place it was a point of law if the act of the accused would amount to any offence ,

facts.text: Magistrate dismissed complaint under s.203 CrPC on June 26, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: the learned magistrate passed his order, dismissing the companyplaint under s. 203 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: Magistrate held mud figure of Ganesa not an object held sacred.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of his order, the learned magistrate observed as follows- The mud figure of Ganesa alleged to have been broken by accused is number an object held sacred or worshipped by any class of persons. Simply because it resembled the God Ganesa held in veneration by a section it cannot become an object hold sacred.

facts.text: Complainant filed revision petition to Sessions Judge on July 9, 1953 under ss.435 and 436 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant moved the learned Sessions Judge of Tiruchirappalli, by his petition in revision, filed on July 9, 1953, under ss. 435 and 436 of the Criminal Procedure Code,

facts.text: Revision confined to offence under s.295 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: for setting aside the order of dismissal of the companyplaint. In the petition filed in the Court of Session, the companyplainant stated that the petition was companyfined to the companyplaint in respect of the alleged offence under s. 295, Indian Penal Code,

facts.text: Sessions Judge dismissed revision on January 12, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge dismissed the petition by an order dated January 12, 1954,

facts.text: Sessions Judge held acts do not amount to offence under s.295 IPC; image was private property not sacred.

anchor.surface_text: holding, in agreement with the learned magistrate, that the acts companyplained of did number amount to an offence under s. 295, Indian Penal Code. In the companyrse of his order, the learned Sessions Judge made the following observations- I agree with the learned Magistrate that the acts companyplained of do number amount to an offence. The accused, who profess to be religious reformers in a campaign against idolatory organized a public meeting at which they broke an earthern image of the God Ganesa. The particular image broken was the private property of the accused and was number in itself an object held sacred by any class of persons

facts.text: High Court dismissed revision under s.439 CrPC on October 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant then moved the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. ... refused to order further inquiry.

facts.text: High Court held mud image of Ganesa not within s.295 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge also agreed with the companyrts below in the reasons given by them for dismissing the petition of companyplaint, and refused to order further inquiry. In the companyrse of his judgment, he discussed the question whether a mud image of God Ganesa, came within the scope of the words any object held. sacred by any class of persons in s. 295, and he answered the question in the negative.

facts.text: Supreme Court obtained special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner moved this Court and obtained the necessary special leave to appeal.

facts.text: Facts alleged in petition not controverted.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the facts alleged in the petition, do number appear to have been companytroverted,

facts.text: Image of Lord Ganesa held sacred by certain classes of Hindus even if not consecrated.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the question of evidence, which had yet to be adduced, it is a well-knonwn fact that the image of Lord Ganesa or any objective representation of a similar kind, is held sacred by certain classes of Hindus, even though the image may number have been companysecrated.

facts.text: Supreme Court held lower courts erred in restricting meaning of s.295 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of these companysiderations, it must be held that the companyrts below have erred in their interpretation of the crucial words of s. 295 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Supreme Court did not direct further inquiry as case stale after about 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: But the question still remains whether, even after expressing our strong disagreement with the interpretation of the section by the companyrts below, this Court should direct a further inquiry into the companyplaint, which has stood dismissed for the last about 5  ,ears. ... we do number direct further inquiry into this companyplaint.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 13, 1954, of the Madras High Court
is whether the petition of complaint, disclosed a prima facie offence under s. 295 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant has urged that the courts below had unduly restricted the meaning of the words of s. 295, particularly, the words any object held sacred by any class of persons , and that the words have been used in their fullest amplitude by the Legislature, in order to include any object consecrated or otherwise,

arguments.claim: Whether object held sacred depends on evidence; facts alleged not controverted; image of Lord Ganesa held sacred by classes of Hindus even if not consecrated (judicial notice)

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the question of evidence, which had yet to be adduced, it is a well-known fact that the image of Lord Ganesa or any objective representation of a similar kind, is held sacred by certain classes of Hindus, even though the image may not have been consecrated.

arguments.claim: Lower courts gave too restricted meaning to 'any object held sacred'; only idols in temples/processions not intended; idols illustrative; includes sacred books like Bible, Koran

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge in the Court below, has given much too restricted a meaning to the words any object held sacred by any class of persons , by holding that only idols in temples or idols carried in processions on festival occasions, are meant to be included within those words. [...] A sacred book, like the Bible, or the Koran, or the Granth Saheb, is clearly within the ambit of those general words.

arguments.claim: Restricted interpretation against established canons of construction; any trivial object regarded sacred falls within s.295; not necessary to have been worshipped

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, placing such a restricted interpretation on the words of such general import, is against all established canons of construction. Any object however trivial or destitute of real value in itself, if regarded as sacred by any class of persons would come within the meaning of the penal section.

arguments.claim: Courts must be circumspect and respect religious susceptibilities/emotions of different classes irrespective of beliefs' rationality

anchor.surface_text: Courts have got to be very circumspect in such matters, and to pay due regard to the feelings and religious emotions of different classes of persons with different beliefs, irrespective of the consideration whether or not they share those beliefs, or whether they are rational or otherwise, in the opinion of the court.

arguments.claim: Lower courts erred in interpretation of crucial words of s.295 IPC

anchor.surface_text: As a result of these considerations, it must be held that the courts below have erred in their interpretation of the crucial words of s. 295 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts unduly restricted 'any object held sacred by any class of persons' to consecrated temple idols or procession idols; general words must be given full amplitude per canons of construction, includes unconsecrated images, sacred books; judicial notice that Ganesa images held sacred; courts must respect religious susceptibilities.

holdings.text: Any object however trivial or destitute of real value in itself, if regarded as sacred by any class of persons would come within the meaning of the penal section [s.295 IPC].
